title: Ontology: Finding Meaning in Data (Palantir RFx Blog Series #1)
summary: Palantir defines ontology as a semantic layer that maps raw data into real-world objects, relationships, and logic. It decouples data pipelines from applications and embeds meaning, permissions, and operations directly into a shared object model.

content.core_thesis: Data has no inherent meaning. Meaning emerges when raw data is mapped into a structured ontology that defines objects, relationships, and behaviors aligned with real-world concepts.

key_components.description: Enterprise-level conceptual entities such as Person, Account, Product, Facility. These are the semantic nouns of the system.
Concrete instances of object classes created by mapping raw data into ontology-defined structures.
Defined semantic connections between object classes (e.g., owns, belongs_to, transacts_with).
Logic applied to objects such as aggregations, transformations, and ML scoring.
Defined state transitions and behaviors that govern how objects change.

architectural_pattern.principle: Applications interact with ontology-defined objects rather than raw tables.

distinctions.vs_schema: Schemas define structure. Ontologies define meaning and relationships.
distinctions.vs_taxonomy: Taxonomies classify. Ontologies encode behavior, logic, and relationships.

implications: Semantic abstraction layer enables multi-agent reasoning over shared object definitions.
Embedding logic in ontology reduces semantic drift across applications.
Ontology-aware agents can operate at object-level abstraction instead of raw data parsing.
Knowledge graphs can serve as ontology infrastructure for AI-native systems.
